Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Taming Uncertainties in Reliable, Real-Time Messaging for Wireless Networked Sensing and Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: Message passing in wireless networked sensing and control systems must be reliable and in real-time. Such design challenges require new models and distributed protocols for messaging that can handle interference locally and accurately, given the basic problem of computing probabilistic path delays is NP-hard. Focusing on single-hop transmission scheduling and multi-hop spatio-temporal data flow control, this project makes novel contributions by proposing two major research tasks: 1) investigation of control-theoretic approaches to online model instantiation, based on the physical-ratio-K (PRK) interference model, and addressing the challenges of large interference range as well as anisotropic, asymmetric wireless communication; 2) developing a lightweight approach to computing probabilistic path delays followed by a multi-timescale adaptation framework for real-time messaging. In particular, the PRK interference model integrates protocol model's locality with physical model's high-fidelity, thus bridging the gap between the suitability for distributed implementation and the enabled scheduling performance. By controlling network operations at the same timescale as the corresponding dynamics, the proposed multi-timescale adaptation framework ensures long-term optimality while simultaneously addressing short-term dynamics. Additionally, this project includes an integrated, multi-level, multi-component education plan. The education activities will raise public awareness, improve student retention and participation of underrepresented groups in computing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transcending the people-centric nature of traditional wireless networks, predictable, real-time wireless networks are expected to enable a wide range of cyber-physical-human (CPH) systems which will transform the way human interact with the physical world, thus having transformative impact on domains such as transportation, agriculture, manufacturing, and power grid. To realize this vision, this project has developed the technology foundation for CPH systems wireless networking. In particular, this project has developed a field-deployable approach to predictable control of wireless interference in data transmission scheduling --- an open problem since the very first wireless data network (i.e., the ALOHA network) was invented in 1970s. The approach features the novel Physical-Ratio-K (PRK) wireless interference model and innovative protocol mechanisms (e.g., control-theoretic approach to model instantiation) that transform the non-local interference control problem into a local control problem and enable agile adaptation to dynamics and uncertainties. The approach is applicable to ad hoc networks and infrastructure networks (e.g., cellular networks), and it is applicable to both immobile and mobile networks. Based on its predictable interference control mechanisms, the project has developed networking mechanisms (e.g., scheduling, power control, and routing) that ensure predictable control of the reliability and timeliness of each packet transmission, in both single-hop and multi-hop networks. The project has also developed innovative approaches to leveraging heterogeneous wireless communication resources and network coding for improved communication capacity and timeliness.

 

The aforementioned wireless networking solutions serve as solid foundations for realizing the vision of CPH systems such as connected, automated vehicles, networked AR/VR, and industrial IoT. This project has helped establish critical collaborations between the PI and industry partners such as Ford Research, which ensure practical relevance of the proposed solutions and facilitate their expected transition to practice. This project has also helped establish interdisciplinary courses on wireless CPH systems, involve graduate and undergraduate students (including female students) in research, and outreach to CPH application communities (e.g., public safety) as well as middle school and high school students.
